metadata.firstNLines:
This is a [Next.js](https://nextjs.org) project bootstrapped with [`create-next-app`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/cli/create-next-app).

## Getting Started

First, run the development server:

```bash
npm run dev
# or
yarn dev
# or
pnpm dev
# or
bun dev
```

Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) with your browser to see the result.

You can start editing the page by modifying `app/page.tsx`. The page auto-updates as you edit the file.

This project uses [`next/font`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/optimizing/fonts) to automatically optimize and load [Geist](https://vercel.com/font), a new font family for Vercel.

## Learn More

To learn more about Next.js, take a look at the following resources:

- [Next.js Documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs) - learn about Next.js features and API.
- [Learn Next.js](https://nextjs.org/learn) - an interactive Next.js tutorial.

You can check out [the Next.js GitHub repository](https://github.com/vercel/next.js) - your feedback and contributions are welcome!

app/layout.tsx.name: layout.tsx
app/layout.tsx.upperLevelSummary: Defines the root layout, global metadata, and font configurations for the application. Integrates global CSS and serves as the foundational wrapper for all pages.
app/layout.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: This file serves as the root layout for a Next.js application, specifically a calculator project. It handles global configuration including the integration of Google's Geist and Geist Mono fonts, the inclusion of global CSS styles, and the definition of application-level metadata for SEO. The RootLayout component acts as a higher-order component that wraps all page content, ensuring consistent styling and HTML structure across the application by applying font variables to the document body.

structure.name: Imports
structure.summary: Imports the Metadata type from Next.js, font utilities from Google Fonts, and the global CSS stylesheet.

structure.name: Font Configuration
structure.summary: Initializes Geist and Geist Mono fonts, defining CSS variables and character subsets for use throughout the application.

structure.name: metadata
structure.summary: Defines and exports the application's SEO metadata, including the page title and description.

structure.name: RootLayout
structure.summary: The main layout component that wraps the entire application. It defines the HTML structure, sets the language to English, and applies font-family CSS variables to the body element while rendering child components.

app/page.tsx.name: page.tsx

metadata.fileDocstring:
*
 * Home page component
 * Renders the calculator in a centered layout

app/page.tsx.upperLevelSummary: This component renders the calculator application within a centered main layout to serve as the project's home page. It acts as the primary entry point by integrating the Calculator component and local CSS styles.
app/page.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: This file defines the primary entry point for the application's home page using a React functional component named Home. It imports a modular Calculator component and CSS styles to render a centered layout. The component's main responsibility is to provide the high-level page structure, including a semantic main container and a page title, while delegating the core logic and interactive UI to the Calculator sub-component.

structure.name: Home
structure.summary: The main page component for the application. It serves as a layout wrapper that renders a title and the imported Calculator component within a styled main HTML element.

components/Button.tsx.name: Button.tsx
components/Button.tsx.upperLevelSummary: Defines a calculator button component supporting various visual variants and click events. Used by ButtonGrid and styled through a local CSS module.
components/Button.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: This file defines a React functional component named 'Button' designed for a calculator interface. It manages button labels, click events, and visual styling through a 'ButtonProps' interface. The component supports multiple visual variants (number, operator, special, equals) and a 'wide' layout option. It dynamically constructs CSS class names by importing styles from a CSS Module, filtering for active properties, and joining them. The button encapsulates a click handler that returns its specific value to the parent component, facilitating a centralized state management for calculator logic.

structure.name: ButtonProps
structure.summary: An interface (though syntactically incomplete in the source) defining the component's props: value (string), onClick (callback), variant (styling category), and wide (boolean layout flag).

structure.name: Button
structure.summary: The main functional component that destructures props, calculates dynamic class names based on the button's variant and width, and returns a JSX button element with an attached click handler.

structure.name: handleClick
structure.summary: An internal arrow function that triggers the onClick prop, passing the button's specific value back to the parent's event handler.

structure.name: classNames
structure.summary: A logic block that constructs a space-separated string of CSS classes by combining the base button style, the specific variant style, and an optional wide style, using filter(Boolean) to remove empty strings.

components/ButtonGrid.tsx.name: ButtonGrid.tsx

metadata.firstNLines:
import Button from "./Button";
import styles from "./ButtonGrid.module.css";

interface ButtonGridProps {
    onButtonClick: (value: string) => void;
}

/**
 * Calculator button grid component
 * Arranges buttons in a 4x5 grid layout
 */
export default function ButtonGrid({ onButtonClick }: ButtonGridProps) {
    const buttons = [
        { value: "C", variant: "special" as const },
        { value: "±", variant: "special" as const },
        { value: "%", variant: "special" as const },
        { value: "÷", variant: "operator" as const },
        { value: "7", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "8", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "9", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "×", variant: "operator" as const },
        { value: "4", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "5", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "6", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "-", variant: "operator" as const },
        { value: "1", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "2", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "3", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "+", variant: "operator" as const },
        { value: "0", variant: "number" as const, wide: true },

components/ButtonGrid.tsx.upperLevelSummary:
Renders a 4x5 grid of calculator buttons that triggers click events via a provided callback.
Used by the Calculator component and depends on the Button component and local CSS modules for styling.
components/ButtonGrid.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: The ButtonGrid component serves as the layout container for a calculator's user interface, specifically organizing 19 buttons into a structured grid. It defines a data-driven array of button configurations, including values for numbers, operators (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division), and special functions (clear, sign toggle, percentage). Each entry in the array specifies the button's visual variant and whether it should occupy double width (like the '0' button). The component maps this data to individual Button components, delegating click handling to a passed-in callback function to maintain a stateless presentation layer.

structure.name: ButtonGridProps
structure.summary: Defines the TypeScript interface for the component's props, specifically requiring an onButtonClick callback function that accepts a string value.

structure.name: ButtonGrid
structure.summary: The main functional component that initializes the button layout and renders the grid. It contains the logic for mapping button data to UI components.

structure.name: buttons
structure.summary: A local array of objects defining the labels, visual variants (special, operator, number, equals), and layout properties (wide) for every button in the calculator.

structure.name: JSX Return
structure.summary: The rendering block that uses the Array.map() method to iterate over the buttons configuration and instantiate Button components within a grid container.

components/Calculator.tsx.name: Calculator.tsx
components/Calculator.tsx.upperLevelSummary: The Calculator component manages application state and orchestrates core calculation logic for the user interface. It is utilized by the main page and integrates internal UI components with external calculation utilities and styles.
components/Calculator.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: This React component implements the logic and user interface for a standard calculator. It manages several pieces of state, including the current display value, the previous operand, the active mathematical operation, and a history string. The component utilizes several 'useCallback' hooks to handle user interactions such as digit entry, operator selection, decimal points, and clear/delete actions. It relies on external utility functions from a calculator library to perform the actual arithmetic calculations and formatting. The component acts as a central hub, coordinating between the UI sub-components ('Display' and 'ButtonGrid') and the underlying calculation logic to ensure a responsive and accurate calculation experience.

structure.name: Calculator
structure.summary: The main functional component that initializes state for the calculator (display, previousValue, operation, waitingForOperand, history) and renders the UI layout.

structure.name: handleNumber
structure.summary: Updates the display when a number button is clicked. It handles the transition from a 'waiting' state to a new input state and prevents leading zeros.

structure.name: handleDecimal
structure.summary: Appends a decimal point to the current display string, ensuring that only one decimal point can exist in a single operand.

structure.name: handleOperator
structure.summary: Processes arithmetic operator selection (+, -, ×, ÷). If an operation is already pending, it performs the calculation first before setting the new operator.

structure.name: handleEquals
structure.summary: Executes the pending calculation when the equals button is pressed. It updates the display with the result, logs the operation in the history state, and resets the operator state.

structure.name: handleClear
structure.summary: Resets the entire calculator state to its initial values, clearing the display, history, and any stored operands or operations.

structure.name: handleBackspace
structure.summary: Removes the last character from the display string. If only one digit remains, it resets the display to '0'.

structure.name: handleToggleSign
structure.summary: Negates the current numerical value displayed on the screen (toggles between positive and negative).

structure.name: handlePercent
structure.summary: Converts the current display value into a percentage by dividing it by 100.

structure.name: handleButtonClick
structure.summary: A dispatcher function that receives a button value and routes it to the appropriate handler (number, operator, clear, etc.) using a switch statement.

components/Display.tsx.name: Display.tsx
components/Display.tsx.upperLevelSummary: This component displays the current input value and calculation history for a calculator interface. It is consumed by the Calculator component and styled via a dedicated CSS module.
components/Display.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: The Display.tsx file defines a React functional component designed to serve as the visual output for a calculator application. It is responsible for rendering two specific data points: the current input value and the historical calculation string. The file utilizes TypeScript for prop validation via the DisplayProps interface and imports CSS modules for localized styling. Although the provided source code contains significant syntax errors, missing keywords, and incomplete JSX tags, its structural intent is to provide a stateless UI component that maps data-driven props to a structured HTML layout consisting of a container and two nested display areas.

structure.name: DisplayProps
structure.summary: A TypeScript interface intended to define the shape of the props passed to the Display component, specifically requiring 'value' and 'history' strings.

structure.name: Display
structure.summary: The main functional component that accepts history and value as props. It returns a JSX structure intended to display the calculation history and the current input value, though the code is currently malformed with syntax errors and missing closing tags.

lib/calculator.ts.name: calculator.ts

metadata.fileDocstring:
*
 * Calculator logic module
 * Contains pure mathematical functions for calculator operations

functionSignatures.name: add
functionSignatures.signature: export function add(a: number, b: number): number

functionSignatures.name: subtract
functionSignatures.signature: export function subtract(a: number, b: number): number

functionSignatures.name: multiply
functionSignatures.signature: export function multiply(a: number, b: number): number

functionSignatures.name: divide
functionSignatures.signature: export function divide(a: number, b: number): number

functionSignatures.name: calculate
functionSignatures.signature: export function calculate(a: number, operation: Operation, b: number): number

lib/calculator.ts.upperLevelSummary: Provides core mathematical logic and utility functions for calculator operations including basic arithmetic, input parsing, and display formatting. This module is used by the Calculator component and contains no local dependencies.
lib/calculator.ts.lowerLevelSummary: This file contains the core logic for a calculator application, implemented in TypeScript. It defines basic arithmetic functions (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division) with error handling for division by zero. It includes a central dispatcher function, `calculate`, which executes operations based on a custom `Operation` union type. Additionally, the module provides utility functions for parsing string inputs into floating-point numbers and formatting numerical results for display, including logic for scientific notation and precision limiting for large or highly precise values.

structure.name: add
structure.summary: Performs addition of two numerical operands and returns their sum.

structure.name: subtract
structure.summary: Calculates the difference between the first and second numerical operands.

structure.name: multiply
structure.summary: Computes the product of two numerical operands.

structure.name: divide
structure.summary: Divides the dividend by the divisor. Includes a safety check to throw an error if the divisor is zero.

structure.name: Operation
structure.summary: A TypeScript type alias defining the allowed mathematical operator symbols: '+', '-', '×', and '÷'.

structure.name: calculate
structure.summary: A dispatcher function that takes two numbers and an Operation type, executing the corresponding arithmetic function via a switch statement.

structure.name: parseInput
structure.summary: Converts a string input into a floating-point number using parseFloat, returning 0 if the input is not a valid number.

structure.name: formatDisplay
structure.summary: Formats a numeric value for UI display. It applies scientific notation for extremely large or small values and uses precision limiting if the string representation exceeds a specific length.

next.config.ts.name: next.config.ts
next.config.ts.upperLevelSummary: Defines the global configuration settings for the Next.js application. Exports the nextConfig object and operates independently of local project dependencies.
next.config.ts.lowerLevelSummary: This file serves as the central configuration hub for a Next.js project using TypeScript. It imports the `NextConfig` type to provide IntelliSense and type checking for the application's configuration. The file defines a `nextConfig` object intended to store custom build-time and runtime settings—such as environment variables, image optimization rules, and path rewrites—which are used by the Next.js framework to customize the application's behavior. The provided snippet is syntactically incomplete but establishes the foundation for these settings.

structure.name: Import Statement
structure.summary: Imports the NextConfig type definition from the 'next' package to enable type safety and autocompletion for the configuration object.

structure.name: nextConfig
structure.summary: Initializes the configuration object for the Next.js application. While the code is truncated, this block is designed to hold specific framework settings and is typically exported as the default module for the Next.js compiler to consume.

metadata.firstNLines:
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "ES2017",
    "lib": ["dom", "dom.iterable", "esnext"],
    "allowJs": true,
    "skipLibCheck": true,
    "strict": true,
    "noEmit": true,
    "esModuleInterop": true,
    "module": "esnext",
    "moduleResolution": "bundler",
    "resolveJsonModule": true,
    "isolatedModules": true,
    "jsx": "react-jsx",
    "incremental": true,
    "plugins": [
      {
        "name": "next"
      }
    ],
    "paths": {
      "@/*": ["./*"]
    }
  },
  "include": [
    "next-env.d.ts",
    "**/*.ts",
    "**/*.tsx",
    ".next/types/**/*.ts",
    ".next/dev/types/**/*.ts",

..name: calculator
..summary: This root directory serves as the foundation for a TypeScript-based Next.js web application. It centralizes project configuration while orchestrating application routing, reusable UI components, and shared utility functions.

app.name: app
app.summary: This directory serves as the root entry point and structural foundation for the Next.js calculator application. It manages global configurations, metadata, and styling while rendering the primary calculator interface.

components.name: components
components.summary: This directory contains the modular UI components and local styles required to build the application's calculator interface. Key functionalities include button grid management, input/history display, and a central orchestrator that manages state and calculation logic.

lib.name: lib
lib.summary: This directory houses the core mathematical logic and utility functions for the application. It provides essential features for arithmetic operations, input parsing, and display formatting.
